revision.text:
General Sir '''William Henry Sewell''', KCB (c.1786 – 13 March 1862) was a senior officer in the British Army.
Of unclear parentage, he was educated at [[Westminster School]] and [[Eton College]] under the name of W.H. Robertson and joined the British Army in 1806 as an ensign in the 96th Foot under the name of William Henry Sewell. He then exchanged to the [[16th Light Dragoons]] and rose through the ranks, via different regiments, to be Lieutenant-Colonel of the [[6th Foot]] in 1817.<ref>{{cite book|title=Wellington's Men Remembered Volume 2: A Register of Memorials to Soldiers|first= Janet & David|last=Bromley|page= 262}}</ref>
He was appointed aide-de-camp to [[William Beresford, 1st Viscount Beresford|General Beresford]], going with him in 1808 to the [[Peninsular War]]. He was present with Sir John Moore’s army at [[Battle of Corunna|Corunna]], [[Battle of Talavera|Talavera]], [[Battle of Busaco|Busaco]], [[Battle of Nivelle|Nivelle]], [[Battle of Nive|Nive]], [[Battle of Bayonne|Bayonne]], [[Battle of Orthes|Orthes]], [[Battle of Toulouse (1814)|Toulouse]] and the sieges of [[Battle of Ciudad Rodrigo|Ciudad Rodrigo]], [[Battle of Badajoz (1812)|Badajoz]], as well as several other minor engagements.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sole.org.uk/sirthom.htm|title=The Right Honourable Sir Thomas Sewell and his Descendants|publisher= The Sole Society|accessdate= 13 August 2016}}</ref>
After serving on Lord Beresford's staff in [[Battle of Maida|Maida]] and South America in 1807 he stayed on to command a Portuguese cavalry regiment from 1816 to 1818. Following his return from the Peninsula he served in India from 1828 to 1854 successively as Deputy Quartermaster General in command at Bangalore, divisional commander at Madras and finally Commander-in-Chief of the Madras Army. He transferred from the [[6th Foot]] to the [[94th Foot]] in 1841 and was made Major-General in that regiment in 1846.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=19989|startpage=1582|date=18 June 1841}}</ref>
In 1854 he returned to England and was made Colonel for life of the [[Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders|79th Regiment of Foot (Cameron Highlanders)]],<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=21534|startpage=937|date=24 March 1854}}</ref> promoted to Lieutenant-General <ref>{{London Gazette|city=e|issue=6938|startpage=530|date=27 June 1854}}</ref> and knighted [[Companion of the Bath|CB]]. He retired in 1856 and in 1861 was elevated to [[Knight Commander of the Bath|KCB]]<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=22524|startpage=2689|date=28 June 1861}}</ref> and promoted full General on 26 November of that year.<ref>{{London Gazette|issue=22569|startdate=4868|date=26 November 1861}}</ref>
He died in Florence in 1862 and was buried at the Protestant Cemetery there. He had married Georgiana Hacking Hamilton, daughter of John Dalrymple Hamilton, in 1831 St George’s Cathedral, Madras. They had several sons and daughters, of whom Henry Robert and John Dalrymple William also became officers in the Army.
According to some reports Sewell was an illegitimate son of the Prince Regent (later George IV).
